Summary In a world where categories define who we are, I like to specialize in not specializing. My passions and interests span across different fields and I am constantly seeking ways to connect the diversity of my skills. By using design thinking and creativity, I am able to navigate these seemingly separate seas. 
 
Professionally, I am working toward becoming a health care provider, an innovator, a holistic health coach, and discovering the next great superfood. Personally, I am an artist, photographer, designer, traveler, vegetarian chef, yogi, blogger, listener, and a do-er. 
 
I want to be someone who can empower others to achieve their optimal health; to restore vitality and enable positive lifestyle changes. Whether that is by creating healthy recipes, inspiring wanderlust for the outdoors, designing spaces and lifestyles promoting health and activity, or by providing integrative, patient-centered care--there is no one-way avenue.  
 
I believe it is important to take a step back and focus on who I am trying to help, while empathizing with their specific abilities or needs. My efforts will always be for the person or community for whom I am serving. Summary In a world where categories define who we are, I like to specialize in not specializing. Experience Director, Epidemiology & Drug Safety IMS Health April 2015  – Present (5 months) Greater Seattle Area Senior Research Consultant Epidemiology Consulting April 2010  –  April 2015  (5 years 1 month) Greater Seattle Area Provide scientific and operational support for a varied portfolio of epidemiologic research projects. Provide critical review of scientific synopses and reports. Develop training curriculum in research methods. Senior Manager, Research Operations Group Health Research Institute 2002  –  2007  (5 years) Greater Seattle Area Managed and led the Research Operations Department, which consisted of more than 120 research staff. Participated in Institute-wide strategic planning and leadership as member of the Administrative Leadership Team. Provided oversight for three major programs: Medical Records, Clinical Research, and Survey Research. Developed and implemented department-specific and Institute-wide policies and procedures related to grants management and study expenditures, human subjects and privacy protections, facilities and space management, and human resources management. Hired, supervised, and mentored research project managers. Oversaw department budget as well as annual budgeting process. Assured compliance with federal regulations. Provided consultation to internal and external colleagues in budgeting, project management, and study design and implementation. Senior Research Project Manager Group Health Research Institute 1998  –  2002  (4 years) Managed operations of two large, multi-site NIH-funded breast cancer research studies. Oversaw development and implementation of study protocols and procedures. Provided leadership as liaison to lead researchers and study coordinators at eight sites nationwide. Developed and led training sessions on study design and data collection at all sites. Performed statistical analyses and wrote scientific reports and manuscripts. Developed and monitored budgets. Participated in grant writing. Oversaw compliance with federal regulations and human subjects protections. Hired, trained, and supervised research staff. Graduate Research Assistant Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center 1996  –  1998  (2 years) Greater Seattle Area Provided epidemiologic research support for a large nationwide study of post-menopausal women’s health. Designed and implemented data collection instruments. Developed algorithms and quality-control measures for large data sets. Analyzed quantitative data, synthesized study results, wrote and published scientific manuscripts. Program Coordinator UCSF 1995  –  1996  (1 year) San Francisco Bay Area As member of clinic administrative team, participated in strategic planning to prepare for hospital shift to capitated care. Developed and conducted training sessions for clinic staff. Served as liaison between clinic staff and hospital management. Developed processes to assess clinic productivity and quality of care. Coordinated the implementation of an HIV/AIDS services grant. Developed and maintained tracking databases of HIV comorbidity and patient satisfaction. Monitored grant goals and objectives. Served as liaison to the City of San Francisco AIDS Office. Summary “Why?” That is a question we all begin asking in the phase of development after we learn to speak and our curiosity, imagination, and creativity skyrocket. This is a question I never stopped asking.  
 
Innately curious, I've chosen a career finding answers in clinical research. I have a unique appreciation for the subjective nature of research in CNS indications, the importance of bias-minimizing trial design, and the priorities of all stakeholders in clinical research. I specialize in sponsor-company leadership, Phase II-IV trial design and execution, and psychometrics.  
 
My Proudest Moments: 
- Stepping into a senior leadership role to bring an underpowered, under-resourced device study back on schedule, which produced statistically and clinically significant results. 
- Obtaining a positive vote from an FDA advisory committee, and ultimately drug-device approval, following months of rigorous project management, meeting preparation, and an NDA re-submission. 
- Receiving FDA approval of an orphan drug following nearly three years of a first-of-its-kind clinical trial. 
 
My Style: 
- Collaboration is key: I am considerate, participative, and consultative. I don’t know everything, I don’t have all the answers, and I find that collaborating often leads to collective genius and connection within a team. 
- Teach a person to fish: I do not only lead by doing; I also lead by teaching. There is no greater reward than developing the strengths and autonomy of others. 
- Always a student: If there’s one thing I’ve learned, it’s that I must never stop learning. I value others' expertise, information sharing, and new ways of approaching problems and processes.  
- No jargon: I use meaningful sentences free of convoluted syntax to communicate. I will never leverage your core competency to make hay by opening the kimono, shifting a paradigm, and scaling the tallest pole in the tent. Why? Because no one knows what that means. 
- Laugh: Everything is more fun with a good sense of humor! Summary “Why?” That is a question we all begin asking in the phase of development after we learn to speak and our curiosity, imagination, and creativity skyrocket. This is a question I never stopped asking.
